Robert Frost, Aerospace engineer
Updated December 31, 2016 · Featured on Forbes
The Moon gets hit by about 2800 kg of meteor material per day.

If we imagine a typical large musket ball with a mass of 28 g, we could imagine 100,000 of them rain down on the Moon each day. That sounds like a lot, but it is a big Moon.

The surface area of the Moon is about 37.9 million square kilometers. If we distribute our 100,000 musket ball meteorites over that area, we get one musket ball for every 379 square kilometers. That's an area a little larger than Canton, Ohio or Glasgow, Scotland. If you lived in either of those cities and every day one musket ball fell from the skies, would you be significantly worried?

The Apollo 11 crew wandered around the Moon in an area of about 752 square meters. If we divide 379 square km by 752 square meters we get 503,718.

That means that if the Apollo 11 crew had stayed on the Moon 503,718 days (1,380 years), odds are that one, yes one, musket ball would come down somewhere in the area they were hanging out.
My addition::
On the other hand, according to National Geographic, annually about 2,000 people are killed worldwide by lightning. Therefore, the average human being, according to these figures has roughly a 1 in 60,000 to 80,000 chance of falling victim to lightning in an average lifetime (of about 65-70 years).
Andrew.

This is off the subject at hand, Tim, I just wanted to ask if you think SpaceX should reconsider the decision not to try to save the Starship crew, in the event of an explosion of the booster. (I think that's their decision - not sure) Anyway, I remember when the Challenger exploded, it was discovered that the crew survived the blast, and only died when the crew compartment hit the water. The lesson I drew from that was that it shouldn't be assumed, now, that a similar explosion would be non-survivable. What if the crew compartment of the Starship were designed to break as a separate section, or with explosive charges set to separate it from the engines, so that the crew compartment weight was minimized. There would be three or four parachutes packed in it, as with the Dragon, designed to deploy automatically. Somebody would have to make the weight calculations, but why wouldn't that be possible? If the Challenger had had one or two chutes, how much weight would that have added? Not that much, probably, and I'll bet those astronauts would've taken their chances of survival with a parachute from K-Mart, over free-falling with nothing at all. Chutes don't weigh that much, do they - relative to the weight of the Starship? I would imagine their weight would be negligible.

Any guess on the starship’s landing trajectory modification to avoid kicking up dangerous debris? We all saw what 1 raptor can do to the ground. When 3 raptors together are blasting the ground, the impact will get much worse FROM A MUCH HIGHER ALTITUDE. And with many Raptors landing the superheavy, debris will be kicked up from a mile up. SpaceX needs a landing trajectory that keeps the exhaust directed onto the debris proof landing pad ... i.e. a vertical descent from a couple miles up. What’s your thoughts? Where I live we get ice storms every year where a thick fog bank rolls through and freezes onto everything it touches. It's what I always think of when the LOX tanks frost up, but my ice is always perfectly clear and this ice is always perfectly opaque. I don't know why it forms so differently and it's probably going to bother me until someone with access to a rocket launch facility gets curious too.

In respondable comment news though: Do you know how thick the ice layer is normally?
